title: The Heather-Moon
author: Williamson, C. N. (Charles Norris)
snippet: A very intelligent custodian, who has written a book about theAbbey, was showing us round at that moment, and telling things about SirRalph Evers, whom the Douglases killed for revenge, on Ancrum Moor, andall about the pillar with the "curly green capital."

title: The Heather-Moon
author: Williamson, C. N. (Charles Norris)
snippet: A very intelligent custodian, who has written a book about theAbbey, was showing us round at that moment, and telling things about SirRalph Evers, whom the Douglases killed for revenge, on Ancrum Moor, andall about the pillar with the "curly green capital."

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Ancrum Moor lies to the right of the road.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: The road strikes off to the right to Ancrum Moor, which is reached by a long straight ascending road, Lilliard's Edge being right in front.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Many of the powerful family of Douglas were interred in this church : among these were James, second Earl of Douglas, who fell at the celebrated battle of Otterburn ; and William Douglas, " the dark knight of Liddisdale," who tarnished his laurels by the barbarous murder of his companion in arms, the gallant Sir Alexander Ramsay, and was himself killed by his god-son and chief, William Earl of Douglas, while hunting in Ettrick Forest Their tombs, which occupied  two crypts near the high altar, were defaced by the English under Sir Ralph Evers and Sir Brian Latoun — an insult which was signally avenged by their descendant, the Earl of Angus, at the battle of Ancrum Moor.
